I am a DSLR photographer. I do a lot of bird photography. I have a nikon 200-500mm ED VR with a Nikon D750, a Canon 6D Mark II with a Sigma 150-650mm, a Pentax K-1 with a Pentax 150-450mm AW, and a Canon 77D with a Canon 400mm L, a Sigma 100-400mm with a Nikon D3400.

I am describing my gear to the reader so he/she will see how my review will be influenced by my current setup. Anytime I carry any of my gear mentioned above, I am looking at a good 4 to 8 lbs of gear strapped on my chest and hiking miles of trail. The Nikon Coolpix P1000 can never beat the image quality of a proper DSLR. The Nikon Coolpix P1000 is NO MATCH against sharpness and clarity of the images that my DSLRs produce. NO MATCH...and that is understandable. BUT...sometimes, I feel like I don't want to haul heavy gear. Sometimes, I just want to enjoy the scenery and the walk but still having the capability to take photos. Sometimes, I just want to be silly and just take photos of anything...a rock, a bird, a raccoon paw print, the bark of a tree. Enter the Nikon P1000.

The Nikon Coolpix P1000 is an excellent point and shoot camera as long you know its limitations. The camera uses a tiny sensor, a smartphone sensor, so low light is the first challenge already. Now, there is a way to squeeze out light from this sensor by going Manual, or Aperture Priority and adjusting the ISO to 3200 or 6400 (max ISO). The next challenge is the 125X zoom power. You can get great quality images between 24-1500mm handheld as long as you keep your shutter speed around 500-1000, and then push the ISO a bit. Shooting handheld with this camera is doable as long you keep your zoom range within a reasonable range. Once you push pass 1500, you are now faced with hand shaking, wind, your breathing, the twitch of your arm, they start multiplying ten-fold as you push your zoom range closer to 3000mm. The next question is: do you need a tripod to push 3000? This is up to you. Remember though, when you push 3000mm even with a tripod, the quality of the image degrades because of the distance and size of the subject. This is a fact and it must be accepted by the user because it's just how the technology was built into this system, and the reality that 3000mm will start picking up heat shimmers, wind etc start showing up. It is the nature of super-telephoto lenses- any lens in the market. Do not be upset or disappointed when you see these issues at higher zooms, it is not Coolpix P1000s fault. It's just the nature of super zooms.

Let's get the weight issue out of the way. It's about 2lbs maybe? Not sure because I am so used to carrying heavy camera gear that having this Coolpix P1000, to me, is very light. It might feel heavy for others not used to carrying heavy camera gear. But for me, this camera is light as "feather" so to speak, in relation to my heavy gear. Anyway, the point is..it's not going to break your hip or back. After you use this camera on several trips and hikes, your body will eventually adjust to the weight.

What about images within ranges of 24-1500? I can say they look good to great. I know this is a point and shoot camera but if you really want to get the best out of this camera, the user needs to learn other forms of shooting styles, particularly using the different shooting modes- M, A, S. Trust me. Learning these other shooting modes will really bring out Nikon Coolpix P1000s capabilities from a point and shoot to a intermediate "DSLR"-like features.

The Nikon Coolpix P1000 also has features like RAW format. Note that if you are using RAW format, the digital zoom is not available. Optical zoom at RAW format only goes up to 3000mm. Note that there are two zooms...Optical and Digital. User needs to read the full manual just in case they notice a function doesn't work; chances are the functionality isn't available at that moment because the camera locked you out because of a setting you made. Again, these are all described in full manual. The Quick manual that came with the camera is just a quick reference guide. You will need to download the full manual free from Nikon USA's website. This full manual will tell you EVERYTHING that you need to know about the camera.

The Coolpix also has other "DSLR" like features like Spot metering, Center-weighted, Matrix. It also has manual AF select, Spot focusing; typical focusing features found in proper DSLRs. You can also set the ISO number. If you want to change ISO without going thru the MENU interface, you can assign the FN button to pull up the ISO numbers. Lots of neat stuff. All of thse are described in the full manual.

What about battery use? You will need an extra battery. Please please use Nikon batteries. Do not use third-party batteries. Since you've already invested $1000 on a camera, there's no reason for you to go cheap on the battery. Bite the bullet and get a Nikon battery. Don't get those Wasabi or Watson batteries. Spend a bit more on real genuine Nikon batteries. Rated at 250 shots according to Nikon. Some ways to save battery power is to not use the Monitor all the time. Have the auto power off setting at 30 seconds.

The Nikon Coolpix comes with a strap, a Nikon battery, a USB cable, a USB charging adapter, warranty card, manual, lens hood, lens cap.

Accessories you need to start with? I strongly suggest getting a UV lens filter for this camera. The filter size is 77mm. I also suggest using a shoulder strap instead of the neck strap that came with the Nikon Coolpix P1000. Never ever strap a camera around your neck. I really think neck straps should not be used for cameras of this size as this causes neck strain. Please get a good shoulder strap. You might want to get a wired Nikon MC-DC2 remote release cord. It's no expensive. Do not get the Nikon Bluetooth remote cord- too expensive. Start with the Nikon MC-DC2. This remote cord helps you press the shutter button remotely (it's wired) to reduce vibration/shaking when you are focusing at a distant object; for example, the moon. You might want to invest on tripod. Just make sure the camera is well-tethered to you when attaching this camera to a tripod.

Overall, I am happy with my Nikon Coolpix P1000. I am still testing all its capabilities. I recommend this camera to those looking for an all in one camera. Again, I can't stress enough about knowing its limitations. It takes great images as long as you know how to utilize its "powers".

And finally, practice practice practice. The camera is just a device, majority of the work will have to come from the user for this camera to come up with great images. Highly recommended camera.

Update: After several months and over 10,000 photos of birds and other wildlife, I have upgraded my review to 5 stars. This is clearly the best birding camera I have ever owned, including a Canon 7D DSLR camera with a 400mm zoom lens. I have found that if I turn the display inward (facing into the back of the camera) it will stay off. The viewfinder also stays off unless I lift the camera to my face to view it. So, I can leave the camera turned on while I take nature walks without running down the battery as fast. This allows me to capture pictures much faster before a bird or other subject moves out of sight. The battery still runs down after about 1.5 hours, but I keep a spare battery in my pocket. This allows me to catch birds in flight almost as easily as the 7D. For birds sitting still, especially at long distances, the P1000 is way better, hands down. Low light performance is also way better with the P1000. Videos of an eagle nest at 1/3 mile using a tripod are very good, as good as our $1600 spotting scope. Viewing the movie as it is being taken on the display screen is also about as good as our spotting scope.

Original review:
The best part about this camera is the electronic viewfinder. It is bright and detailed enough to make the camera like a hand-held image-stabilized spotting scope with automatic focus and brightness adjustment. I watched an eagle pair working on their nest from 1/3 mile away. The view through the view finder was almost as good as a $1600 spotting scope (85mm x 60). That alone is worth the price. I tried to upload a hand-held movie of it, but the upload conversion turned it into garbage. The original movie was almost as good as the view through the viewfinder.

The still pictures at long zoom look substantially less detailed than what the eye sees through the viewfinder. That tells me that the image processing (frame averaging, etc.) in human vision is better than in the camera. So, we can expect that future super-zoom cameras will improve dramatically as the image processing becomes faster and more sophisticated.

Low light performance, especially autofocus at long zoom settings is bad, but it is easy to quickly switch to manual focus. The focus ring is easy to operate.

I compared this to my old Nikon P900 and found no obvious improvement in zoom reach. The picture is bigger at max zoom, but the amount of detail is about the same. So the increase is size, weight was for naught.

I still consider this a substantial upgrade because of the brighter and more detailed viewfinder and the easy manual focus. That makes a huge difference in finding the bird or other target, composing the picture, and adjusting brightness and focus.

If I could redesign the P900 to my liking, I would make its grip bigger to fit my large hands, make the battery bigger, make the the battery charge indication more accurate, replace the viewfinder with the one from the P1000, and give it an adjustment ring and manual focus like the P1000.

• Lens does not gather enough light
• AF does not work that great. I have many of slightly out of focus images.
o AF frequently fails at high zoom and/or low light
o AF can take almost a second to search

I bought this camera specifically for it's long focal-length video capability and had my doubts about what it could actually do. I've spent a LOT of money of long glass over the years and have a 1000mm AF f8 sitting in a closet to prove it. The claim that this thing was good to 3000mm optical was hard to believe but intriguing. After a month or so of use I have to say the camera is radically good. But the thing I like best about it might not be an advantage to you.

At extreme focal lengths the effect of the atmosphere becomes more and more apparent. Images shimmer and in some circumstances the air seems to boil. I love using this thing to shoot video of things moving -- cars, people walking, traffic -- and at 3000mm on a hot day, the effect is very beautiful but odd. I set this thing up on a tripod in the middle of the street and point it down the road to where a freeway on-ramp is a mile and a half away, and can clearly see vehicles make the turn at that distance. All the vehicles -- cars, trucks, bicycles, and pedestrians -- are stacked up between the camera and the on-ramp and they're all moving under their own power as well as in the boiling air. It is a very theatrical view.
.
This is probably not what you're looking for if you're doing bird photography or all sorts of other work. If you're working closer, the shimmer would presumably be less.

The autofocus works reasonably well although it struggles to get a lock at long focal-lengths. It is somewhat slow but will follow-focus fairly well. Images are sharp and clean even at the end of the zoom.

The P1000 does not have many of the controls or features found on professional video cameras but it has enough that I'm happy with it. It works for me as an extreme-zoom lens with a fairly simple video camera attached.

My two cents, your mileage may vary, opinions void where prohibited.

I have own many Nikon cameras (and even some Canons) including the D850. I have purchased telephoto lenses for these DSLRs with disappointing results in their reach. I've had this camera for two days now and have worked thru the 175-page manual, so I feel safe posting some initial thoughts. First impression: it's BIG, and it's heavy. It is half-again bigger and heavier than my Lumix GH-4. But the Lumix doesn't have a 3000 mm zoom lens, which is the Nikon's raison d'être. And that is where it shines. The sensor is small but the pictures are sharp. 24 mm wide angle and 3000 mm tele both produce nice images. (The photos I uploaded are 24, 1000, 2000, and 3000 mm, -- straight out of the camera. No tripod, just laying on a table, so the 3000 isn't as sharp as it could/should be.)

The menus are easy to navigate. The menu options are much more limited than the DH-4 but the most-used features are there, and are easily accessible. I would like to have more than one "Fn" button for quick access to menu items, but that's a small nit. There are physical buttons for exposure compensation, self-timer, focus mode, and flash settings. The manual focus works very easily, and I found it really handy at the long zoom settings. Overall, it's well done, with obvious design sacrifices for the enormous zoom range. I'm sure my DH-4 will remain my primary camera, but this Nikon seems to fulfill its main purpose quite well. (I took one star off for its bulk)

Side note -- I'm not sure most people will find the extra zoom power over the earlier P900, which has a 2000mm tele, worth the several hundred dollar premium for the P1000. Plus the 1000 weighs an extra pound or so. What swung it for me was the RAW capabilities of the P1000, plus a few other features that a lot of folks might not care about.

Many have complained of this camera being heavy. I've taken it out to take photos and enjoy the lesser weight than that of a 500mm or 600mm lens attached to a Nikon D7100 and get tremendously closer photos than I could with either of those lenses. The image stabilization works very well but you should still use a tripod when zooming out to the limits for a better shot. Remember to turn the stabilization off when using the tri-pod. The mechanics in the lens can cause motion even when on a tripod.

I have taken amazing photos of the moon. At full extension of the lens, you only get a part of the moon. Craters are crisp and there are more visible than I had ever gotten with a large detachable lens. Have taken close shots and still be in focus that I never would have thought possible . It has a macro selection but it won't be needed unless you get extremely close.

There are some downers, i.e. total pixels and small sensor. Still, I have taken excellent photos with other cameras that were the same. The main reason I didn't like 16 mp was taking shots of birds that usually were a great distance away. This required cropping the photo which decreased the size of the file. With the P1000, no cropping is necessary for those distant birds. As a birder, this is a grand plus for me. Also, not having to change lenses for each situation is handy.

Everyone has their own idea of what is ideal in a camera and lens. The P1000 fills a spot for the type of photography I do - wild birds and animals. One camera covers all situations.

At long focal lengths, the P1000 gets much better pictures than a P900.

Using a tripod I got the attached sequence of a cormorant who was basking in the sun using purely optical telephoto at 24mm, 275mm, 3000mm. Using combined optical and electronic telephoto, on a tripod, I attach shots at 3600mm. 6000mm, 12000mm. I have a feeling that electronic telephoto is largely done by cropping.

Hand held, I attach pictures of a heron at 1000mm, a cormorant swimming at 2000mm and at 3000mm, all within about 200 feet of the camera. I also attach a hand held picture of a far subject, namely a cupola that was about 1500 feet away, at 3600mm. These were hand held without any support like a fence or a tree.

So this is a very capable camera, both on a tripod and, owing to good image stabilization, hand held.

Battery life ? So far I have taken 291 pix, with lots of zooming in and out, and the battery indicator is now showing half depleted.

As backup for long trips I purchased two spare batteries and a charger for $18 (Powerextra 2x EN-EL20a Replacement Battery & Car Charger Compatible with Nikon Coolpix P1000). The charger also plugs into a 110 volt wall socket. Average review was 4.4 stars but several users warned that these batteries don't last all that long, so I'm going to keep the OEM battery in my camera bag and use the cheapies and see how well they do.

To protect the camera I bought an Amazon basics medium size camera bag which fits well, though would not protect against major impacts.

These pictures are not the highest possible resolution for the camera. I'm having a great time with the P1000
Although I had to have it replaced once, Amazon service was amazing. Shoot raw and the lower resolution of the camera is not an issue for me. JPEG only does not do what I enjoy, although is probably more than enough resolution for general posting sizes on line.
The "digital extended zoom range is an issue and interesting. I have not used it enough to speak to it, beyond saying it may be an issue. My first one did not work at all. The replacement works fine, and works a little differently than the full manual suggests. First, be ready to select 'RESET TO FACTORY SETTINGS" on the menu, even right out of the box, to get the digital zoom activated. Then, it is, as designed, available in some and not all shooting modes. The manual says "not in bird mode," yet mine does have digital zoom access in Bird mode. I have not decided if it is a useful feature or not. The lens itself, autofocus, features of the camera, etc., are really fun! Buttons are well-located. I suggest ordering an extra battery or two, along with the quick charger. Otherwise, out of the box, charging is only while in the camera. The five stops of optical image stabilization is astounding. i like the camera, and ive had fun with it taking all my photos. ive recently upgraded though, and i feel like the p1000 will be on the shelf for a little bit before it sees use again.

Clearly the zoom lens is the best feature. In my photo series you can see the ability to zoom in on a target well over 1KM away. You can almost read the brand of sunglasses the boat driver is wearing. The image stabilization is excellent. I also owned the Nikon P-900. Also an excellent camera. Unbelievable reach with its 3000mm lens. Persons will have trouble holding the camera still enough at max. range to avoid a slightly fuzzy picture in many cases. However it can be done with some practice. Great 4k vids and pics. Wonderful feel when holding this slightly larger than normal camera. Its heft and weight, however, I find are useful assets when filming at lens max. If you own a P900, you might want to think twice about this camera, however. It is a Bridge Camera, not a DSLR, so you have both the advantages and disadvantages of that you get, and give up, in going to a Bridge Camera. If you do a lot of Nature Photography, or just live where you get to see a lot of nature out your back door, this is the camera for you!!! You will get those long distance pics of Mother Nature at her best that you would miss with another camera. And while I do wish it had better battery life, when out in Nature, that little failing is not enough to dampen my enthusiasm for this camera. I do recommend this camera.

The smart image setting is great as well. It isn’t super fast at recovering for the next picture after taking a picture, especially after videos or multiple shots. If you are looking into this camera it is probably because of the 3000mm built-in zoom and macro capability. I have used this camera on a couple of big trips-The Galapagos Islands and a recent Italy & Greece trip. I have found that it really beats carrying around extra lenses. The weight is tolerable for a full day of shooting if you support the camera when not taking pictures or else use a shoulder strap.
While the extreme zoom can present problems with noise and framing issues under cloudy or gray conditions, it is excellent on a clear, sunny day. The photos I have attached of the Hephaestus Temple that I shot while descending the Acropolis, are a good example of this cameras zoom capability on a perfect day. Except for reducing these images in size for the web, they are not re-touched. I find this camera to be a great solution for people who don't want to carry a lot of equipment.

The hawk in this picture is from 30 yards. The goose in the second picture, is also in the middle of the third picture; down the canyon and in the river. I take this camera everywhere.

We are having a great time with this camera. We use it mostly for bird pictures where we want more options than our high end point and shoot gives us. I use this for surveillance, mostly. It's an amazing tool! I do wish that it was lighter, but I can't get this kind of zoom with anything comparably sized... So I keep that in perspective.
One feature that this unit doesn't have that I liked about the p900 is GPS. I do keep it connected to my smart phone, so I just make sure it's actually updating the location.

Great job, Nikon! Now hurry up and get that remote to me for this thing!!!

It's without peer for distance wildlife photography. The p-1000's sensor is wired from the back, and it takes better pictures than the p-900, though it operates at the same resolution. The equivalent zoom in a dslr would run more than $20k, and weigh enough to make hiking around with it impossible without a safari. I can get shots with this camera of things I could formerly see only with a spotting scope. Small sample of images below.

The P100 is a fantastic camera for anyone who enjoys taking nature photos. Is is a bit hefty compared to a "pocket-sized" point and shoot, but it is much lighter than a camera and a 600mm lens. It is also a lot cheaper! The image quality may not be as good; however, it is more than adaquate for the average "hobby" photographer. The bald eagle in the included photo was more than 300 yards away and the image is still very sharp. This camera is also great for sporting events and concerts where cameras with seperate lenes are often not allowed. I also own a P900, which I thought was amazing until I purchased its "big brother". Now it sits in its case most of the time.

Yes, the sensor is small but you don't have to degrade your images by cropping and enlarging them either. It all evens out. If you know anything about digital cameras, you know that a small image sensor is necessary to achieve large amounts of optical zoom in small packages. Small packages you say? Yes, for a 3000mm equivalent focal length this camera is not that big and it is definitely not heavy. The P1000 is about the same size as my Nikon D810 with a 24-120mm lens but weighs less. They are different tools for different jobs and the P1000 does its job very well.

IT is a fun camera for long range as nothing can really get you that close. For that, I enjoy it BUT you must adjust your expectations. The sensor is VERY small. Smaller than the main sensors on many high end phones. Testing its wide end performance vs my Mate 20x, the Mate 20x blew it out of the water in detail. The P1000 has that watercolor look to the photo.
When going up to around 2000mm it still looks good enough for your normal IG, FB posting. RAW helps you get more out of the image if you know how to handle RAW files. After 2000mm the aperture drops into diffraction territory and by F8 (3000mm) it is heavily affected by diffraction give images a pretty soft look. You can of course work on them and get decent results for smaller social medial sharing but dont expect beautiful images you can pixel peep.
So adjust your expectations and you may have fun with it.

I recently purchased a used P1000 in almost "like new" condition from a different vendor. I tested it for a few days. I went to a nearby lake to shoot birds and nature and compare it with a full-frame Nikon camera (24 megapixels image sensor 6000 x 4000 pixels, equipped with a Sigma telephoto lens 150-600mm plus Sigma 1.4x teleconverter)
As a reminder, the sensor on the Coolpix P1000 is a cropped sensor that has 16 megapixels (4600 x 3400 pixels), while the sensor on the full-frame Nikon was a 24 megapixels sensor.
I put a 77mm UV filter on both the Coolpix and the Sigma zoom lens.
I was particularly interested in testing the focus function of the Coolpix since people complained of having problems. Being in full daylight, the Coolpix focus worked very well over the entire range. One problem people have is that they try to use the full 3000mm zoom magnification on a subject that is too close. In order for the lens to focus at 3000mm the subject has to be at least 7 meters away from the camera.
Also, I found out that the camera has some problems focusing at 3000mm when it is handheld, and there is little light available, such as in the late evening (or dusk).
When I set the zoom of the Coolpix to 600mm, to be just like the Sigma lens on the full-frame Nikon, the focusing of the two lenses was comparable, although the Sigma was a bit faster.
When I tried to take pictures of flying birds, the Sigma lens on the Nikon full-frame was better, faster than the Coolpix lens. The constant-AF of the Coolpix works, but it is not as responsive.
As an overall impression, images on the Coolpix are, perhaps, not as "crisp" as those taken with the more expensive, full-frame Nikon camera, but that is not an issue for me. I still got some beautiful images that only the large zoom made possible. To see what this camera can do I am attaching two pictures of the same osprey sitting by its nest. I merged the pictures into a single image to make it easier to post online. Pictures were taken in full daylight with the Sigma lens at 850mm (lens + teleconverter) and the Coolpix at 3000mm. In both cases, cameras were hand-held. Pictures were captured in RAW format, and both images were converted into JPGs and then reduced in size by a factor of 4, so they are smaller and easier to post online. Nothing was cropped out from either image. The original size in pixels of both images is depicted. In both images I measured the number of pixels available for the bird itself. As you can see, with the full-frame, 24 megapixel Nikon camera and Sigma lens at 850mm, the bird height was 730 pixels. By comparison, with the Coolpix camera at 3000mm, the bird height was 2500 pixels or about 3.5 fold larger. This makes perfect sense since the 3000mm is also about 3.5 times larger than the 850mm. If my Nikon full-frame camera had a 48-megapixel sensor (~$3000 for a mirrorless camera body only), the bird height would have been about 1100 pixels, still less than half of the Coolpix camera.
Therefore, I think the p1000 Coolpix is a fantastic purchase. You can use it to bring subjects close and take pictures at magnifications that would only be possible with expensive professional cameras and professional lenses, costing many thousands of dollars.
Yes, the Coolpix images are not quite as sharp as those taken with professional Nikon lenses, the camera has a bit of trouble focusing in low light at 3000mm and is also not as responsive when taking pictures of subjects in motion (birds flying). For me, all of these shortcomings are overcome by the powerful zoom capability of the camera, as shown by the two images posted.

I want to review this camera simply from the perspective of a birder. I have been using the P1000 for about 8 months now. I generally use it for taking photos that help me identify birds and other wildlife that I see while hiking and traveling. I end up often using the P1000 as a spotting scope for birds because it has a longer reach than my 12x50 binoculars. I also enjoy taking photographs good enough to post on my blog and to enlarge to print and hang in my office. The P1000 works well for all of my needs. Truthfully, it has made photography so enjoyable that my occasional hobby of wildlife photography has become something of an obsession.

The superzoom is, of course, the most important feature of the camera for birding and it has a very impressive range. No other camera, even my digital SLR Nikon with a 500mm zoom lens, can come close to the capabilities of the P1000’s lens. And, while the P1000 is a heavy point and shoot camera, it is lighter and more maneuverable than my DSLR and 500mm lens were in the outdoors.

I also looked for a camera that didn’t require that I change the settings for each and every situation I encountered. Wildlife does not wait around for you to change the ISO or the f-Stop. The birding setting on the P1000 has generally been perfect in most wildlife situations. For more challenging birds in flight situations, the camera allowed me to preset a user preference setting. I just have to change the control dial from the “bird” setting to “U” and I am set up for birds in flight.

Overall, I was looking for camera that would easily go wherever I wanted to go and the P1000 has filled that need. If you want a camera that you can use right out of the box to take great bird pictures, this one is it. If you want to slowly learn how to take better pictures using more DSLR-type features, this camera will allow you to grow as a photographer. It is also advanced enough to keep many more experienced amateur photographers happy. If I want to manually focus, manually set the aperture, manually set the shutter speed, etc., I can do that on the P1000. But I don’t have to when I don’t have time to do so. That kind of flexibility of both a high performing point and shoot and a mostly successful DSLR should put the P1000 on the wishlist for many birders. It has made my birding so much more enjoyable and was certainly worth the $1000 price.

One other note: I have had excellent warranty service from Nikon in the past and that has made me a very loyal Nikon buyer. Nothing about this camera has changed my mind about Nikon’s quality products.

There are a few drawbacks, but plenty of other reviewers have dwelt ad infinitum on those deficiencies. The p1000 is not perfect. My best advice is to get a detailed manual like the “Photographer’s Guide to the Nikon Coolpix P1000” and figure out how to overcome those deficiencies. It will help you learn to utilize more of this camera’s capabilities.

I think you can assume it’s a pretty impressive camera for most purposes. 5 stars. But what I’m writing here for is to provide warnings about the few shocking shortcomings that I learned about the hard way, by surprise, on shoots, in real time. (Which make is particularly painful for high resolution nature videographers.)

1) There are many claims that you can connect to an app, and control it via the app (wifi): This has not even close to succeeded once. The app has failed 100% of the time. Nikon acknowledges it. And if it were to connect, it would shift the camera away from 4k, and lock it into 1080p until you disconnect the app. When the app is repaired and connected to your canera, the camera immediately becomes a far worse camera.

2) There are many claims that you can buy a remote control for this cam. And control it with the remote. (Bluetooth.) There are further claims that you can connect an HDMI cable to the cam. Both are true seperately. But connecting your HDMI cable disconnects your remote. Connecting your HDMI cable nullifies 4k and locks you to 1080p until you disconnect it.

There is no remote monitoring & recording of this camera.
You cannot plug in any app or monitor and hit record remotely.
The only version of remote triggering possible is: Unmonitored. You can set it to 4k and not connect any app or cables, back away, and hope your subject is in frame, and hit record with a remote... and just hope it started recording. - This camera is best: IN your hands, with you operating it.

3) There is no clean HDMI output. It’s in the manual. It’s in the menu. But it was never implemented. You can switch the clean HDMI OUTPUT, on. And you will still have 100% of the screen readout displayed on your hdmi monitor. - The reason for CLEAN HDMI (which is uncompressed video signal that hasn’t been squished down into a compressed video file to be fit on your SD card) is to record the uncompressed, higher quality internal signal, to an external recorder. - This was advertised. It did not happen. Boo! - I want the full sensor readout. Uncompressed. Without writing on the screen.

4) This is the worst low light camera I’ve ever owned. It’s shockingly bad. Nobody is worse than this. But it’s lowlight. That’s not Nikon’s job. It’s Sony’s job. When you need low light go to Sony. A7Siii if you can afford it. But in truth, this camera here is far more similar to the original a7s. No zoom on the a7s though.

5) YOU CANNOT POWER THIS THROUGH USB... unless you use NIKON’s USB cable and wall outlet converter. The wall plug that comes with the camera, is smart. It is computerized. It sends a pin-1 data handshake to the cam that says: accept usb power from me. - So no. A power brick will not work. You MUST be near an outlet to use usb power. On the road that might mean you need your car running next to it to use an inverter. Which is ridiculous. But the good news is: BATTERY LIFE ON THIS THING IS AWESOME.

6) The vibration reduction / image stabilization in this thing is genuinely terrible. - I say that using it alongside a sony a7R with a Tamron internal is lens. The two are not on the same planet of quality. Good IS costs 4X as much. Just dont take the brags about stability seriously. It’s your job to stsbilize this camera. They didn’t make a serious effort to do so.

Enough for now. Will report changes & improvements over time.

I bought the P1000 one week ago from a local big box store rather than Amazon simply because (a) I wanted to handle it before making a final decision to buy and, (b) patience is not my forte (at the time, Amazon was out of stock). I'm an admitted Nikon Coolpix fan who enjoys shooting wildlife and landscapes so zoom is important to me. I started out with 42X P530 that I gifted to a family member after getting my current 60X B700 both of which I acquired here on Amazon. Prior to buying the B700, I had considered getting the P900 but one factor led me not to buy it: no RAW capability.

When I saw the announcement of the September introduction of the P1000, I was intrigued by the possibilities that 125X zoom presented for wildlife and landscapes images. With 2+ times the zoom and a feature set that included 99.9% of those on the B700 plus more, I was more than casually interested. The P1000 takes more images (7 vs 5) in the continuous shooting mode. It also has a Bluetooth connection that allows remote shutter release when WiFi is not available when using the ML-L7 remote control, although that device seems to be a bit of a unicorn currently. It also has twice the maximum ISO, a faster Wide lens (Max Aperture Wide is 2.80 vs 3.30) although the B700 has faster Telephoto lens (Max Aperture Telephoto is 6.5 vs 8.0). Factors like the latter raised some other concerns.

The obvious ones were its size and weight compared to the B700. I'm often hiking on trails in state/national parks, forests and wildlife refuges to get to areas of interest so weight is particularly important to me. Based on my experience with the B700, I was comfortable that it was securely attached to my Amazon Basics monopod - i.e., I wasn't worried about it snapping off the attachment stud and having the camera go crashing to the ground. The P1000 definitely looked like it would need a sturdy but luggable tripod. The advertised battery life was about 100 shots shorter than the B700. Other things like a 16 MP resolution (P1000) vs 21 MP resolution (B700) sensor were also an issue although, since the B700 and P1000 have the same physical sensor size and type (1/2.3" BSI-CMOS), they should provide the same level of control over the depth of field when used with same focal length and aperture. Finally, there was the economic factor. Was the cost of the camera and the "must have" accessories (carrying case, UV and CPL filters, another high speed SD card, the previously mentioned tripod, etc.) justifed by the additional capabilties? In my mind, the answer to that question and all the noted concerns could only be addressed by taking the camera into the field and looking at the unedited image quality.

Other than reducing the size of the attached pictures (from 4608 x 3456 pixels > 1920 x 1440 pixels) to accomodate this review, these jpegs are unedited - i.e, no manipulation of the RAW data and subsequent conversion to jpeg. Note that the 1st & 2nd shot were taken from the same spot with and without zoom. The rest are just targets of opportunity during two days of developing a first impression of what the P1000 can do.

Bottom line: Despite my concerns about the P1000's weight and size, I've found that carrying it, framing shots quickly (motorcycle rider, for example) and shooting without a monopod/tripod produces excellent unedited image quality, at least to this amateur's eyes. While I will keep my B700, the P1000 is a keeper.

Nikon's Coolpix division hasn't always been first choice for many photographers including myself over the last 15 years or so. Until the P900/A900/B700 cameras I considered them to be nearly irrelevant.

However, with the A1000/P1000 and even the B700 Nikon's Coolpix division is improving in all areas that annoyed me about them in the past. Many of the quirks and irritating issues in their designs have given away to more logical handling and build design, as well as excellent choices in adding features etc. for the price.

The P1000 is no exception. Starting on the outside it's an extremely well built and intimidatingly capable looking camera that handles nicely, it's got ample external controls in the right places for those who like to take control of the camera. The tilt and flip screen is also an excellent design choice, along with the addition of including quite a good electronic viewfinder. Overall Nikon has made something truly unique here, and that isn't something I say often about cameras in my reviews. The P1000 claims an optical zoom of 125x but the difference simply isn't that distinguishable. You can actually view YouTube footage yourself of the P1000 and compare it to the P900. The difference just isn't that apparent. I dunno, there are probably some other variables at play that eventually leads ever increasing optical zoom towards diminishing returns. The P1000 feels like it can zoom 10% further, maybe?

On the bright side, the controls and interface are much more responsive and snappy.

Also, the 4K is nice I guess, but it doesn't help my type of filming much. If you're looking for a super close-up shot of animals or flowers, I can see it being a benefit, but it doesn't do much to help improve the picture quality of a lighthouse from 5 miles away. The zoom also isn't as smooth or linear as it was in the P900, it's very twitchy and sudden. The P900 halted at the end of the digital zoom, making it easy to transition to the optical zoom. The P1000 doesn't have that. The transition is violent and makes the video look odd. It also feels like there is some weird stabilization or digital image manipulation mechanism which unpredictably tugs or jerks at the video. I'll play around with it some more and update this review. It could just be some settings that I need to disable. In the mean time, it's obviously the only camera on the market that can do anything like this without getting into the 5 figure price range, so kudos to Nikon in that regard.

I am satisfied with it, it just wasn't the exponential leap in performance from the P900 like I thought it would be.

A review for having used this 8 months

PROS

- Well, you wanted some real zoom and here it is

CONS

- The camera is massive and equivalent to carrying a 15lb dumbbell around your neck
- At full zoom you’re going to run into atmospheric distortion that makes most images useless. Hot days, cold days at this distance everything just becomes a blur
- You probably want this or wildlife pics, and birding is fine- but anything moving is going to get lost with the slow zoom speed and trying to find the target
- You’d think for the size they might make it a bit more rugged, but it is a delicate little flower. Don’t take this out in the rain, Don’t take this out on cold days, don’t jostle it moving around
- You might think you have a heavy duty tripod that will work keep this steady, but you are wrong. The lens is so front heavy extended almost any tripod is useless.
- You’re paying $1k for a sensor that isn’t even as strong as the newest generation iPhones. For the price point you could go get some a low end mirrorless full frame with some real ability
- The manual ring I thought would be a big improvement over the P900 and was a big selling point, but outside a still life its not very useful. Its almost a silly little thing to twirl now and again
- Autofocus at long range just….doesn’t. It’ll find a target, look ready to shoot and then drop out of focus when you hit the shutter
- Supposedly you can get a blurry pic of Jupiter or Saturn, but the camera refuses to focus on a tiny bright spot in an all dark sky.

TL;DR: This was my 3rd Superzoom from Nikon, and the most disappointing. The P500 was a small camera with decent range and perfect for hiking and birdwatching. The P900 had better range but was twice as big and nowhere near as sturdy.
The P1000 looks like it should be top of the line with such zoom capability but it’s has so many points against it I definitely would recommend spending 1K on this dumbbell of frustration.

Soy un fotógrafo aficionado. Estoy precisamente en el proceso de migrar a un nivel un poco más profundo de estudio y práctica. Tengo una cámara DSLR Nikon D3000 y sustituí una Nikon Coolpix P520 por esta Coolpix P1000. Descubrí que en esta fase de incursión en la fotografía, mi estilo fotográfico es logrado con mayor facilidad mediante la versatilidad de la lente zoom, más que estar usando la DSLR con objetivos intercambiables ( que ofrecen muchas virtudes en términos de calidad de imagen ), además del elevado costo de inversión ( los lentes intercambiables son muy costosos ). Además, necesitaba una cámara que me ofreciera la rapidez del modo automático para los eventos familares que no requieren de mucho trabajo de composición, pero que a su vez, me ofreciera las virtudes de los modos semiautomáticos y el modo manual para la creación artísitica con más paciencia y tiempo. He encontrado que la Nikon P1000 me ofrece todo lo que necesito en este aspecto, hasta el momento. La calidad de imagen no puede ser comparada con la calidad que ofrecen los lentes fijos intercambiables de las DSLR, pero es muy, muy buena. Para un aficionado principiante que está por primera vez adquiriendo un equipo y que en realidad no está muy seguro de si va a continuar con la fotografía, en lo personal no recomendaría este equipo porque, para empezar, debido a la naturaleza de sus características, es muy pesado. Para un aficionado de este tipo, yo recomendaría una bridge más ligera o, si lo prefiere, una DSLR.
Ahora, en cuanto a las caracterísitcas de la Nikon P1000: me asombró su avance tecnológico en lo que a la rapidez de compensación y sensibilidad a la luz tiene. ¡ Pude tomar, increíblemente, una fotografía de la Luna inclusive en el modo automático ! Eso no puede ser logrado sencillamente por muchas cámaras. Pero la P1000 incluso tiene un modo ya prefabricado para tomas exclusivas de la Luna. Pude hacer fotografías en modo automático y luego las repetí en modo manual para ver las diferencias, y fueron mínimas, esto es, muchas fotos en el modo automático, la Nikon P1000 las toma con una nitidez, balance de blancos y compensadas de una manera muy notable y muy aceptable.
